theory.movingATerm.oldText: <head>Moving a term</head><par>Suppose we have the equation <inline-math/> and (for whatever reason) we want to get rid of the term <inline-math/> on the left. To do so, the first step is to <skill-link>subtract <inline-math/> from both sides</skill-link>. When we add or subtract a term from both sides of the equation, the equation still remains valid. In this way we get <block-math/> Subsequently, we can see that on the left side adding <inline-math/> and subsequently subtracting <inline-math/> has no effect. We can hence <skill-link>cancel these sum terms</skill-link> to get <block-math/> Note that we have removed the term <inline-math/> from the left side, while keeping the equation valid. The result is that <inline-math/> has moved to the right side of the equation. Where it used to have a plus sign on the left, now it has a minus sign on the right.</par><par>But what if we started with a different equation, containing a minus sign? Like <inline-math/>? In this case the procedure would have been nearly the same, but if we now want to get rid of <inline-math/> on the left, we have to <skill-link>add <inline-math/> to both sides</skill-link>. This gives <block-math/> On the left, we can <skill-link>cancel sum terms</skill-link> again, to end up at <block-math/> Note that we have once more moved the term <inline-math/> to the other side of the equation. Where it had a plus sign on the left, it now has a minus sign on the right.</par>

theory.shortCut.oldText: The short-cutWe can summarize the above ideas into a useful short-cut. We can always move a term to the other side of the equation.If the term was added (had a plus sign) on the original side, then it will be subtracted (have a minus sign) on the other side. So turns into .If the term was subtracted (had a minus sign) on the original side, then it will be added (have a plus sign) on the other side. So turns into .Using this idea, we can also directly move terms around, without applying the in-between steps.

Or alternatively, if the term is being subtracted (has a minus sign), add this term to both sides of the equation. For the example, we subtract to get .Cancel sum terms to get rid of the term that has to be moved. For the example, we have disappearing, leaving the equation as .Note that you can also use a short-cut: if a term is originally added on one side, it will be subtracted on the other side, and vice versa.
